Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Scalable Statistical Validation and Uncertainty Quantification for Large Spatio-Temporal Datasets
Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer simulations, satellites and various other technological advances have paved the way into unprecedented scientific territory by generating volumes of previously uncollectable datasets. Properly utilizing these new data products to promote scientific discovery requires that they, first, be (i) validated and (ii) paired with an appropriate measure of uncertainty. Validating a data product entails comparing "synthetic" data (e.g., computer model simulations, remote sensing measurements, or statistical predictions) with observational counterparts to substantiate the digital data for its use in scientific discovery. Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is a necessary component to validation and entails accounting for and stating the uncertainties associated with scientific conclusions derived from digital or observational data. The purpose of this research is to promote scientific discovery using digital data products by developing statistical methods to perform validation and uncertainty quantification.

Given the strong need to perform, and the substantial challenges facing, statistical validation and UQ, this research will (i) develop new validation strategies for simulated and digital datasets based on scientifically motivated features; (ii) develop multivariate spatio-temporal statistical models that can be used to implement, and perform UQ for spatio-temporal data products; and, (iii) develop scalable computation techniques for fitting the developed spatio-temporal statistical models. This research will implement these techniques on data products in atmospheric, agricultural and environmental sciences to facilitate their use in scientific inquiry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Given the vast amount of digital and observational data produced to study atmospheric, environmental and agricultural processes, this project seeked to extend and develop statistical methodology to perform validation and uncertainty quantification for various data products.  Specific goals for this project included development of new validation and emulation strategies for simulated and digital datasets and development of new multivariate spatiotemporal models and scalable computational techniques for fitting statistical models to digital data. During this project we introduced methodology for feature-based validation of a popular coupled magnetosphere-ionosphere model. We also developed validation theory using spectral coherence for comparing numerical model solutions to digital data products. We developed statistical methodology for identifying various sources of error and uncertainty in a land surface model. Simulation of random fields is fundamental for statistical purposes; we introduced a new simulation approach for generating very high resolution nonstationary random fields based on classic field deformations.

In addition to new statistical methods and theory, this project resulted new validation and uncertainty quantification for a popular near-Earth space model as well as land surface model used in climate and land use change studies. In particular, the Lyon-Fedder-Mobarry (LFM) model is a coupled magnetosphere-ionosphere model whose mathematical definition contains uncertain parameters. We estimated these parameters by comparison to satellite-based data, and developed a feature-based validation strategy for the LFM’s ability to replicate field aligned current structures. Second, we showed that accounting for various sources of error in the Community Land Model was important to adequately capture uncertainty in model parameters that are important for understanding evapotranspiration.

Broader Impacts 

This project resulted in numerous training opportunities for students, including ten undergraduate or graduate students at the University of Colorado who gained interdisciplinary training in statistics and domain sciences such as astronomy, climate and atmospheric science. Examples of student projects include validation and calibration of a popular magnetosphere model, parameter estimation for a popular land surface model, stochastic modeling of solar irradiances and development of stochastic weather generators. The PI also taught at summer camps for area high school students during this project, exposing young minds to statistical thinking and applications. 

Society regularly relies on information from satellites, such as global positioning system location services, communication services, as well as data assimilation needs required for operational weather forecasting. These satellites can be affected and disrupted by large geomagnetic disturbances, and thus it is crucial to have physical models that can adequately represent these processes to aid in understanding and forecasting of threatening events. Our work provides an important step forward in the development and validation of such physical models, with potential impacts on society's reliance on satellite information.  Moreover, climate change is an important obstacle for humanity; climate models rely on accurate modeling of land surface characteristics.  Our work has improved estimates of the popular Community Land Model (CLM) by better calibrating it to observational data, which supports accurate Earth system representations in climate models. Finally, power grid operation is a national security issue, and power fluctuations in high penetration solar energy scenarios can hamper grid operation. Our work in downscaling of satellite-based products may help for future energy infrastructure planning studies.
